prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The water emission lines are expected to be as broad as the CO and [CII] emission lines we have already detected, ~500km/s. Omont et al. 2013 showed that the water and mid-J CO line profiles were similar. We place the two 1.875GHz basebands next to each other to ensure continuous frequency coverage. We tune the both basebands to ensure sensitivity to any high-velocity gas which may be present in these systems. Given the broad lines expected in these sources, we request spectral averaging of 16 channels in order to lower the data rate while ensuring sufficient flexibility for further averaging later.
We want high enough spatial resolution to resolve the sources and make a lens model. Cycle 0 imaging had 0.5 arcsec resolution and these were all resolved, so that's where we start.

How we estimate line fluxes: We start with L_IR, which we measure from ALMA, SPT, APEX/LABOCA, and Herschel/SPIRE and PACS photometry. We adopt L_H2O\L_IR =9.2^-6 from Yang et al. 2013. We get dV from average of CO and C+ (Omont etal 2013 showed water traced mid-J CO). Then we get the total line flux (SdV). Next we have to estimate resolved line flux per beam and we use our lens model. Going from total integrated flux to flux per beam can be tricky. We do this in two different methods and take the average. The first (more conservative) method takes the flux and spreads it out in a perfect Einstein ring and then divides by the number of synthesized beams that fit along the circumference. This method yields between 10-20 beams per source. The second method takes the intrinsic source size derived from our ALMA Cycle 0 continuum imaging and lens models, multiplies by the magnification to get the observed source area, and then divides by the solid angle of the synthesized beam. This method yields roughly 3 beams per source.

The water emission lines are expected to be as broad as the CO and [CII] emission lines we have already detected, ~500km/s. Omont et al. 2013 showed that the water and mid-J CO line profiles were similar. We place the two 1.875GHz basebands next to each other to ensure continuous frequency coverage. We tune the both basebands to ensure sensitivity to any high-velocity gas which may be present in these systems. Given the broad lines expected in these sources, we request spectral averaging of 16 channels in order to lower the data rate while ensuring sufficient flexibility for further averaging later.

We want high enough spatial resolution to resolve the sources and make a lens model. Cycle 0 imaging had 0.5 arcsec resolution and these were all resolved, so that's where we start. The largest angular scale is the Einstein diameter and is <4arcsec.

How we estimate line fluxes: We start with L_IR, which we measure from ALMA, SPT, APEX/LABOCA, and Herschel/SPIRE and PACS photometry. We adopt L_H2O\L_IR =9.2^-6 from Yang et al. 2013. We get dV from average of CO and C+ (Omont etal 2013 showed water traced mid-J CO). Then we get the total line flux (SdV). Next we have to estimate resolved line flux per beam and we use our lens model. Going from total integrated flux to flux per beam can be tricky. We do this in two different methods and take the average. The first (more conservative) method takes the flux and spreads it out in a perfect Einstein ring and then divides by the number of synthesized beams that fit along the circumference. This method yields between 10-20 beams per source. The second method takes the intrinsic source size derived from our ALMA Cycle 0 continuum imaging and lens models, multiplies by the magnification to get the observed source area, and then divides by the solid angle of the synthesized beam. This method yields roughly 3 beams per source.

The water emission lines are expected to be as broad as the CO and [CII] emission lines we have already detected, ~500km/s. Omont et al. 2013 showed that the water and mid-J CO line profiles were similar. We place the two 1.875GHz basebands next to each other to ensure continuous frequency coverage. We tune the both basebands to ensure sensitivity to any high-velocity gas which may be present in these systems. Given the broad lines expected in these sources, we request spectral averaging of 16 channels in order to lower the data rate while ensuring sufficient flexibility for further averaging later.

We want high enough spatial resolution to resolve the sources and make a lens model. Cycle 0 imaging had 0.5 arcsec resolution and these were all resolved, so that's where we start. The largest angular scale is the Einstein diameter and is <4arcsec.

How we estimate line fluxes: We start with L_IR, which we measure from ALMA, SPT, APEX/LABOCA, and Herschel/SPIRE and PACS photometry. We adopt L_H2O\L_IR =9.2^-6 from Yang et al. 2013. We get dV from average of CO and C+ (Omont etal 2013 showed water traced mid-J CO). Then we get the total line flux (SdV). Next we have to estimate resolved line flux per beam and we use our lens model. Going from total integrated flux to flux per beam can be tricky. We do this in two different methods and take the average. The first (more conservative) method takes the flux and spreads it out in a perfect Einstein ring and then divides by the number of synthesized beams that fit along the circumference. This method yields between 10-20 beams per source. The second method takes the intrinsic source size derived from our ALMA Cycle 0 continuum imaging and lens models, multiplies by the magnification to get the observed source area, and then divides by the solid angle of the synthesized beam. This method yields roughly 3 beams per source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 Continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Integrated continuum fluxes in band 9 for these sources are between 200-400 mJy for these sources. This is robustly determined from our SPIRE observations. From our ALMA band 7 imaging we know the lens model, so we can deduce the flux per beam and it is ~13 mJy for our faintest source. For a 10 sigma detection per beam, this would require 2 minutes of integration for an RMS depth of 1.3 mJy. We aim for a factor of x2 deeper, or 8 minutes per source because we are still dominated by overhead time, and the L_IR we can measure is heavily dependent on this flux measurement.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the continuum we are selecting the default continuum setups.

We want high enough spatial resolution to resolve the sources and make a lens model. Cycle 0 imaging had 0.5 arcsec resolution and these were all resolved, so that's where we start. The largest angular scale is the Einstein diameter and is <4arcsec.

Integrated continuum fluxes in band 9 for these sources are between 200-400 mJy for these sources. This is robustly determined from our SPIRE observations. From our ALMA band 7 imaging we know the lens model, so we can deduce the flux per beam and it is ~13 mJy for our faintest source. For a 10 sigma detection per beam, this would require 2 minutes of integration for an RMS depth of 1.3 mJy. We aim for a factor of x2 deeper, or 8 minutes per source because we are still dominated by overhead time, and the L_IR we can measure is heavily dependent on this flux measurement.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to detect and image water lines and infrared luminosity in three lensed starforming galaxies at z~3 from the SPT survey. With the lensing, we will achieve 1 kpc spatial resolution in the source plane. This will be the first time water is spatially resolved in galaxies at high redshift. We will test the recently observed and remarkable linearity of the L_H2O/L_IR correlation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
